title: FinTech Regulation and Legal Policy
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: This course examines the legal and regulatory aspects of Fintech, particularly in the context of Hong Kong and Mainland China, to set the foundation for a practical understanding of the legal environment in which Fintech develops and evolves. The topics covered in this course include, amongst others, the general regulatory framework for the financial markets, the specific policy for Fintech, the regulatory approach towards Fintech, equity crowdfunding regime, P2P Lending rules, robot advisory services, electronic and alternative payment systems, digital currency, program trading, contract law basics and Regtech. Given the nature of the course, a comparative approach will be adopted to examining the topics covered. The course is essential for students intending to pursue a career in the Fintech industry.
outcome: At its completion, the students should be able to demonstrate knowledge and understanding of FinTech regulation and legal policy particularly in the context of Hong Kong and Mainland China, identify and analyze the legal issues that typically arise in the subject area, evaluate legal rules in this area from a comparative perspective.
syllabus: Industrial and professional workshops or seminars
required_readings: Reference materials will be provided in the lecture notes and reserved in the University’s library. URLs to videos showed in the lectures are also included in the lecture notes.

title: Optimization Methods
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR2520 or ESTR3500 or SEEM2420 or SEEM3440
description: This course introduces the essentials of optimization methods, including models, solution methods, and programming techniques. Topics cover linear programming, integer linear programming, nonlinear programming, and convex programming. It will highlight applications of these methods in Fintech, such as asset allocation, portfolio management, and data analysis.
outcome: At the completion of this course, students should   1. Have fundamental knowledge of the art of modeling problems arising from FinTech with linear programming, integer programming, nonlinear programming and convex programming.  2. Be familiar with solution methods for solving linear programming, integer programming, nonlinear programming and convex programming.  3. Be able to solve linear programming, integer programming, nonlinear programming and convex programming with the assistance of computer.
syllabus: This course introduces the essentials of optimization methods, including models, solution methods, and programming techniques. Topics cover linear programming, integer linear programming, nonlinear programming, and convex programming. It will highlight applications of these methods in Fintech, such as asset allocation, portfolio management, and data analysis.
required_readings: F.S. Hillier and G.J. Lieberman, Introduction to Operations Research, 9th Edition, McGraw-Hill, 2010 S. Boyd and L. Vandenberghe, Convex Optimization, Cambridge University Press, 2004

academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: Industrial and professional workshops or seminars related to Financial Technology practicum
outcome: At its completion, the students should understand the field of Financial Technology, how to plan for and develop their career, and how to make ethical decisions.

title: Financial Innovation and Structured Products
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: The course of Financial Innovation and Structured Products provides a quantitative introduction to derivative markets. In it, we will focus on (i) the fundamental mechanics of futures, swaps and option markets, (ii) risk neutral evaluation theory of asset pricing, (iii) numerical procedures related to derivatives evaluation and risk managements, (iv) the principle of financial engineering and structured product design and their applications, and (v) financial crisis and regulation.
outcome: At the completion of this course, students should be able to:  1. Understand fundamental mechanics of derivative markets and the economic impacts of derivative products in risk management;  2. Apply the general principle of no-arbitrage asset pricing to evaluate structured products and to design related hedging strategies; 3. Perform implementations of basic numerical procedures for asset evaluation;  4. Understand the principle of financial engineering and structured product design, and able to carry out some basic analysis on the riskiness of such products;  5. Understand the destabilizing potential of derivative products and the importance of financial regulation.
syllabus: This provides a quantitative introduction to derivative markets. In it, we will focus on (i) the fundamental mechanics of futures, swaps and option markets, (ii) risk neutral evaluation theory of asset pricing, (iii) numerical procedures related to derivatives evaluation and risk managements, (iv) the principle of financial engineering and structured product design and their applications, and (v) financial crisis and regulation.
required_readings: Options, Futures, and Other Derivatives, 9th Edition by John C. Hull  Pearson, 2014.
recommended_readings: Risk Management and Financial Institutions, 4th Edition by John C. Hull Wiley, 2015.  Derivatives Markets, 3rd Edition by Robert L. McDonald  Pearson, 2012.

title: Introduction to Financial Infrastructures
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: This course provides an introduction to financial infrastructures. Topics include trading venues and platforms, securities settlement systems, payment systems, system links that facilitate cross-border transactions, central counterparties and clearance, cybersecurity infrastructure for financial services industry, infrastructure-related systemic risk and its impact on monetary and financial stability.
outcome: At the completion of this course, students should be able to understand the design, operation and management of various financial infrastructures. Students should also be able to identify infrastructure-related risks and analyze their impact.
syllabus: This course provides an introduction to financial infrastructures. Topics include trading venues and platforms, securities settlement systems, payment systems, system links that facilitate cross-border transactions, central counterparties and clearance, cybersecurity infrastructure for financial services industry, infrastructure-related systemic risk and its impact on monetary and financial stability.

title: Advanced Database Technologies
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Prerequisite: SEEM3550
description: To support high-speed online payments, one important issue is efficiency and another important issue is reliability for millions of payments to be transferred among accounts. This course introduces the advanced topics in database systems. The topics include query processing and optimization, transaction management, concurrency control, recovery systems, parallel databases, and distributed database systems.

title: Behavioral Analytics
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: Behavioral analytics is a recent advancement that reveals customer behaviors. In this course, we will focus on (i) how to use optimization techniques to design survey questions and to collect data that are relevant to customer behaviors, (ii) theories of customer behaviors, especially those under risk, (iii) how to use data mining techniques to reveal customer behaviors, and (iv) psychological biases in customer behaviors and their impact on financial and business decisions.

title: Data Mining for FinTech
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: This course introduces key techniques on data mining, including data preprocessing, classification, association rule mining, and clustering and outlier detection. Applications of these techniques in financial market data will be discussed with hands-on practice on data mining packages.
outcome: At the completion of this course, students should be able to:  1. Perform data analysis with a data mining approach which includes data preprocessing, data integration, data mining, result evaluation and presentation.  2. Formulate a real task into a data mining problem and choose an appropriate method as the solution, according to problem characteristics, data distribution, and constraints etc.  3. Evaluate the mining results and present them, able to interactively tune the mining process based on users’ feedback.  4. Apply data mining to applications in financial technology domains and help managerial decision making.
syllabus: This course introduces key techniques on data mining, including data preprocessing, classification, association rule mining, and clustering and outlier detection. Applications of these techniques in financial market data will be discussed with hands-on practice on data mining packages.
required_readings: Introduction to Data Mining by P.-N. Tan, M. Steinbach, and V. Kumar  Addison Wesley, 2005.
recommended_readings: Data Mining: Concepts and Techniques, 2nd edition by Jiawei Han and Micheline Kamber Morgan Kaufmann, 2006.  Data Mining: Practical Machine Learning Tools and Techniques with Java Implementations, 2nd edition by I. H. Witten and E. Frank Morgan Kaufmann, 2005.

title: Financial Informatics
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: This course introduces basic concepts, models, techniques, and applications on financial data analytics. Topics include processing and analytical techniques for data streams; processing and searching high-dimensional data; big graph analysis; Web mining; recommendation systems for Web applications. The applications may involve financial data processing and analysis, time series, portfolio management, social networks, recommender systems, and so on.

title: Internet Finance
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: This course provides students with the fundamentals in the operations and management of Internet finance. It will cover overall applications of Internet-based technologies such as mobile payments, social network, search engines, cloud computing, and big data on the financial sector. Specific topics include third-party payments, Internet currency, P2P lending, crowdfunding, and the use of big data in financial services. The course adopts case studies as the major means of teaching and learning.

title: Introduction to Blockchain and Distributed Ledger Technology
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt

description: The course will cover the technical aspects of cryptocurrencies, blockchain technologies, distributed ledger technology and their applications. Students will learn how these systems work and how to develop secure software application that interacts with the Bitcoin network and other cryptocurrencies.
outcome: At the completion of this course, students should be able to:  1. Understand the blockchain technologies, distributed ledger technology, cryptocurrencies, etc. 2. Develop secure software application that interacts with the Bitcoin network and other cryptocurrencies.

title: Natural Language Processing for FinTech
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: The course aims at equipping students with an overview of latest natural language processing (NLP) technologies that have been increasingly adopted in finance sector. The course will introduce basic concepts of NLP and the advanced developments based on machine learning, especially deep learning. The topics of word representations, sequence modeling, large language models, and conversational AI will be further explored. Based on the introduced foundation in NLP, multiple financial applications will be introduced to illustrate how NLP techniques, e.g., text mining, sentiment analysis, conversational AI and large language models, can increase productivity in various scenarios, including general financial data processing practice and specific RegTech and InsurTech use cases. Students will have ample opportunities to apply the learned techniques in hands-on implementation on course projects.

title: Final Year Project I
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: The course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to carry out, under the supervision of an academic staff, an independent project with research elements in financial technology.
outcome: 1) Be able to identify and have a basic understanding of the literature related to the project topic. 2) Be able to define and complete a project that utilizes results in the literature. 3) Be able to perform a critical review of the project. 4) Develop technical writing skills.
syllabus: The course includes, but are not limited to, the following elements: literature review, modelling, system design and implementation, project evaluation.
required_readings: Literature review materials will be recommended by the project supervisor.

title: Advanced Financial Infrastructure
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
description: This course provides an advanced examination of financial infrastructures, which include trading venues and platforms, securities settlement systems, payment systems, cross-border transactions interlinks, central counterparties and clearance, cybersecurity, and systemic risks. It requires students to undertake project work with a view to make concrete their understanding of the underlying technologies enabling Hong Kong’s financial infrastructure. The student projects will be required to explore the implications of new financial services technology, in particular, the licensing prerequisites, regulatory controls and supervision such new services necessitate. Students will have to form groups and select a particular infrastructure area, e.g. electronic payments or lending, and conduct a deep analysis of its operations, and thereby creating new/enhanced service propositions. It is intended that project teams will be able to create prototype solutions through collaborating with, for example, the Hong Kong and Science Technology Park (HKSTP), Cyberport, ASTRI, or other CUHK labs. Upon completing this course, students should have acquired advanced understanding of components of financial infrastructure, and its significance in the financial services sector.
outcome: By the end of this course, student will be able to 1. Be intimate with the technology and infrastructure supporting financial payments and transactions; 2. Design and implement strategies in the infrastructure to guard security given the recognition of its importance to the financial industry;  3. Understand the function of central counterparties and clearance, both for funds payments and transfers of securities; 4. Identify infrastructure-related systemic risk and its impact on credit risk, competitiveness and monetary and financial stability; and 5. Implement related infrastructure tools for regulatory and risk management purpose.
syllabus: Week 1: Recap and overview of financial infrastructure  Week 2: Payment systems and components Week 3: Clearing systems and components Week 4: Securities systems and components  Week 5: Interim project presentations (project groups) Week 6: Distributed ledger technology and its possible usage Week 7: Digital identify and know your customer Week 8: Guest lecture: innovation in financial infrastructure Week 9: Control environment and systemic risk Week 10: Cyber security Week 11: Discussions on Hong Kong’s Status as an International Financial Centre  Week 12: Final project presentations (project groups) (external judges from industry to be invited)
required_readings: Course notes will be provided by the instructor.
recommended_readings: Randall E. Duran. Financial Services Technology: Processes, Architecture, and Solutions. 2nd edition. Cengage Learning Asia Pte Ltd. 2016.  Lee, Ruben. Running the World’s Markets: the Governance of Financial Infrastructure. Princeton University Press, New Jersey, 2011.  Hong Kong Monetary Authority, Financial Infrastructure in Hong Kong, Second edition February 2013.   Hong Kong Monetary Authority, Financial Technology Infrastructure for Hong Kong December 1997.

title: Applied Blockchain and Cryptocurrencies
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology;Exclusion: CSCI5590 or IERG5590
description: The course introduces the basic underlying cryptographic concepts and technologies of blockchain as a method of securing distributed ledgers in all digital transactions. The significances of trust, anonymity and consensus mechanisms are discussed. The course also further explains the application of blockchain to cryptocurrencies and smart contracts. Examples of public and private blockchains are discussed with emphasis on the applications of blockchain in Finance.
outcome: On completion of this course, students should be able to: 1. Understand the cryptographic concepts of blockchain as a distributed ledger; 2. Describe the issues of trust, anonymity and consensus mechanisms; 3. Describe and understand the differences between different types of blockchain structures; 4. Understand the applications of blockchain in cyptocurrencies and “smart” contracts, as well as their challenges; and 5. Understand the applications of blockchain technology in Finance.
syllabus: Week 1 : Introduction. Basics of Cryptography and Cyber-Security Week 2 : Public/Private Keys, Hash Functions, & Application of Cryptographic Tools to Online Banking Week 3 : Basics of Blockchain, Distributed Ledger Technology, Trust, Anonymity Week 4 : Types of Blockchain: Public vs Private, Permissioned vs Permissionless, Application of Cryptography to Blockchain Week 5 : Blockchain Consensus: Byzantine General’s Problem, Transactions, Mining,  Week 6 : Proof-of-work, Proof-of-stake Week 7 : Application of Blockchain Technology to Cryptocurrencies: Bitcoin and alternative coins, Online Wallets, Exchanges, Regulation, Initial Token Offerings Week 8 : Smart Contracts: Algorithmic Decision Making  Week 9 : Public & Private Blockchain Examples: Ethereum, Hyperledger Week 10 : Blockchain as a Service (BaaS), Scaling Blockchain Week 11 : Application Examples of Blockchain in Finance, Summary Week 12 : Invited Seminar
required_readings: Course notes will be provided by the instructor.
recommended_readings: Bitcoin and Cryptocurrency Technologies: A Comprehensive Introduction, by Arvind Narayanan, Joseph Bonneau, Edward Felten, Andrew Miller, Steven Goldfeder  Research Perspectives and Challenges for Bitcoin and Cryptocurrencies, by Bonneau, Miller, Clark, Narayanan, Kroll and Felten  Cryptocurrency Online Bibliography, maintained by Jeremy Clerk

title: Quantitative and Algorithmic Trading
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
description: The industry landscape of investment, trading, and risk management has been revolutionized by computing technologies, data science, and financial engineering. To progress in tandem with the changes in the industry, the topics covered in this course leverage on the recent developments in portfolio theory, empirical finance, and quantitative and algorithmic trading. In addition to mathematical modeling, an important part of this course is the practical aspect: computational implementations with statistical tests. Given that implementation and test procedures are involved, this quantitative finance course is algorithmic and hands-on in nature.
outcome: The objective of this course is to help students understand deeply by applying various quantitative and algorithmic methods to solve problems of practical relevance to financial trading and investments. By the end of this course, students will be able to 1. Compute market index from its component stocks, and the fair value of index futures contract; 2. Conduct a test about the market efficiency to determine which stock price is a random walk and which is not; 3. Understand the mean-variance portfolio theory and construct alpha and “smart” beta strategies;  4. Estimate market liquidity from trading data; 5. Understand basic strategies of high frequency trading and algorithmic trading, and be familiar with the fundamental IT architecture related to HFT; 6. Be familiar with statistical arbitrage; and 7. Conduct Backtesting.
syllabus: Week 1: Introduction to Electronic Market Week 2: Introduction to Python Week 3: Market Efficient Hypothesis, Random Walk, and Variance Ratio Test Week 4: Statistical Analysis on Price Data Week 5: Portfolio Theory and Mean-Variance Investment Week 6: CAPM and APT Week 7: Multi-Factor Analysis of Expected Returns Week 8: Factor investments and Smart Beta Week 9: Statistical Arbitrage Week 10: Volume, Slippage, Liquidity, and Market Impact Models Week 11: High-Frequency Trading  Week 12: Backtesting
required_readings: Course notes will be provided by the instructor.
recommended_readings: Portfolio Construction and Risk Budgeting (4th Edition), Bernd Scherer, Incisive Financial Publishing Ltd,2010  Quantitative Investment Analysis, 2nd edition by Richard Armand. DeFusco Dennis W McLeavey; Jerald E Pinto, John Wiley & Sons, 2007  Algorithmic Trading, E. P. Chan, John Wiley, 2013

title: Financial Technology Internship
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology
description: The objective of the course is to allow students to acquire a basic understanding and the skills of the practical aspects of the financial technology profession. To qualify for the award of the subject credits, the student must (a) attend regulatory workshop provided by such regulatory authorities as the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, Securities & Futures Commission, and Insurance Authority, and (b) attach to a company in a financial technology related post as approved by the Professor-in-Charge for no less than 12 weeks. The student will have an academic supervisor as assigned by the Professor-in-Charge and an industry supervisor from the company. There will be a mid-term company visit by the academic supervisor. At the end of the internship, the student must give a presentation to the academic and industry supervisors, and submit a report summarizing what the student has done and learnt from the internship. The student’s grade will be determined by (1) the presentation, (2) the student report and (3) a testimonial from the industry supervisor.The internship should normally take place in the summer term after a student has finished the first two semesters of studies. Part-time students can decide to undertake the internship in the summer term of either the first or second year of studies.Students are recommended to seek the Professor-in-Charge's comment on potential internship opportunities before enrolling in the course.
outcome: At the end of the course of studies, a student should be able to 1. Have a good understanding and appreciate the characteristics of a financial technology work environment, including employer expectation, management structure of a financial technology team, industrial standards and practices, trends and common issues in the financial technology industry, etc.; 2. Carry out basic duties in a financial technology work environment; 3. Exhibit good etiquette in the workplace; 4. Work independently as well as in a team environment; and 5. Communicate effectively and efficiently with peers, supervisors and possibly also clients.
syllabus: The objective of the course is to allow students to acquire a basic understanding and the skills of the practical aspects of the financial technology profession.  To qualify for the award of the subject credits, the student must (a) attend regulatory workshop provided by such regulatory authorities as the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, Securities & Futures Commission, and Insurance Authority, and (b) attach to a company in a financial technology related post as approved by the Professor-in-Charge for no less than 12 weeks.  The student will have an academic supervisor as assigned by the Professor-in-Charge and an industry supervisor from the company.  There will be a mid-term company visit by the academic supervisor.  At the end of the internship, the student must give a presentation to the academic and industry supervisors, and submit a report summarizing what the student has done and learnt from the internship.  The student’s grade will be determined by (1) the presentation, (2) the student report and (3) a testimonial from the industry supervisor.

title: Elements of RegTech for the Financial Market
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
description: This course introduces students to a dynamic financial landscape, where safeguarding market fairness, efficiency, and security is more important than ever. With financial regulations now empowered by technologies like AI, machine learning, and advanced data analytics, this course examines how regulatory frameworks adapt to monitor trading, detect abuses, and enforce compliance in real-time. Expert speakers from the fields of information technology, finance, and law provide firsthand insights into both foundational and cutting-edge RegTech. Students will gain not only essential skills in regulatory frameworks but also hands-on training in presentation, interview, and job-readiness skills. This comprehensive experience is designed to launch students into impactful roles in the evolving FinTech and RegTech sectors.
outcome: By the end of this course, students will be able to 1.    Understand Core Financial and Regulatory Principles: Equip students with a strong foundation in financial markets and the regulatory frameworks that ensure market safety, fairness, and efficiency, emphasizing their practical application in today’s global economy.2.    Gain Proficiency in Digital Asset and Blockchain Technologies: Provide students with the technical knowledge needed to navigate digital assets, blockchain, and tokenized finance, including the legal and compliance aspects of cryptocurrencies and decentralized finance.3.    Develop Practical Skills in Compliance and Risk Management: Teach students how to apply RegTech tools and techniques to real-world compliance challenges, focusing on AML/KYC, transaction monitoring, and cybersecurity within the financial and Web3 ecosystems.4.    Refine Professional Communication and Presentation Skills: Foster essential skills for clear and effective communication with legal and financial professionals, including techniques for presenting complex information, managing client relationships, and delivering persuasive presentations.5.    Cultivate Job-Ready Skills in Interviewing, Networking, and Career Planning: Prepare students for careers in finance and RegTech with hands-on training in interviewing, resume-building, and professional networking, ensuring they can stand out in competitive roles.6.    Engage with Industry Leaders and Current Market Trends: Through guest speakers and interactive discussions, students will gain insights from industry experts on the latest trends in FinTech, RegTech, and digital finance, building a robust understanding of where the industry is headed.
syllabus: Week 1: Introduction to Course / Legal Systems / Intellectual Property RightsWeek 2: Financial Markets 101 – Finance, Technology and the Regulator – Foundational ClassWeek 3: Compliant Data - Fixed Income ValuationWeek 4: Compliant Data - Rapid development of data and technology in the sustainable finance spaceWeek 5: Digital assets 101 – Background, Developments, and the Regulatory Approach - Foundational ClassWeek 6: Digital assets – Regulatory approach to stablecoins and beyondWeek 7: Digital assets – Digital Money, e-HKD and the regulatorWeek 8: Digital assets – Forensic analysis in digital assetsWeek 9: RegTech in Web3 - how a virtual insurer underwrites Web3 risks using GenAI Week 10: RegTech - How to talk to a lawyerWeek 11: Navigating the Quantum Frontier: Blockchains, Post-Quantum Cryptography, and the Future of Digital AssetsWeek 12: Final presentationWeek 13: Final exam
required_readings: Course notes will be provided by the instructor.
recommended_readings: Course notes will be provided by the instructor.

title: Topics in Financial Technology Innovations
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
description: This course aims to provide students with the views of global, and in particular China and HK FinTech innovation landscape, including virtual banking and other business model innovation, associated opportunities and challenges. It covers topics including digital lending, digital payment, big data analysis application, FinTech partnership & incubation, Open API, digital product propositions, organizational design to support innovation. This is relevant for students who are interested to work in innovation-related departments in traditional institutions, FinTechs or intend to initiate a start-up. The course also covers the latest development in financial technology innovations and offers case studies.
outcome: At the end of the course of studies, students will have acquired the ability to 1. outline the essence of FinTech innovation and different business model applications across myriad markets globally; 2. understand towards the differences between virtual banking and traditional banking, FinTech and virtual banking, and the technological applications in different markets; 3. design different virtual banking products with industry experts sharing first-hand experience and form good understanding on the regulatory and technological implications regarding virtual banking in global landscape; and 4. create and spur innovation in different organizations.
syllabus: Lesson 1: What is FinTech innovation? • Definition of innovation and impact to financial industry • Background on global FinTech trend and various vertical segments • Design-led thinking approach and customer-oriented mindset (essence: customer journey mapping and customer experience creation)  • Difference between the West and the East  • Introduction of the course assessment framework  Lesson 2: What is virtual banking v.s. traditional banking? • Difference between virtual banking and traditional (online) banking • In-class discussion • Introduction of global virtual (digital) banking market development • Background on global virtual banking landscape  Lesson 3: Is virtual banking a FinTech? • Introduction of virtual banking product offerings and value proposition • Case study of virtual banking: Monzo and KaokaoBank • FinTech: unbundle v.s. rebundle • Case study of “rebundle” FinTech: Revolut and Wealthfront • Introduction of essay paper (project work): identify 2 FinTechs who are in the same vertical segment (1 each for the West and the East), share views on their business model innovation similarities and differences; comment if this can be applied in Hong Kong and why  Lesson 4: FinTech business model innovations – virtual banking • Introduction of business model innovation • Virtual banking business model archetypes • Opportunities and challenges of virtual banking • Case study on virtual banks (in-class discussion)  - Global : ING Direct and N26  - China: PingAn Orange Bank, Webank and Mybank  Lesson 5: Virtual banking product offering – payment and lending • Introduction of digital payment development and impact to credit card  - Guest speaker • Introduction of consumer finance and P2P development in China, difference with traditional bank lending • Application of big data analytics and machine learning technology  - Guest speaker  Lesson 6: Virtual banking product offering – account and Open API • Introduction of HK remote account opening and impact to virtual banking  - Guest speaker • Introduction of HK Open API initiative and comparison with global practices • Case study on Open API (in-class discussion)  - UK : Starling marketplace, HSBC Connected Money  - HK: ZhongAn, MoneyHero • Technology risk impact arising from Open API • Introduction of presentation (course work): identify a virtual bank that is launched in Hong Kong and analyze their business operating model, suggest plans on their iteration if you’re the management team  Lesson 7: Virtual banking - title: Financial Technology Entrepreneurship
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
description: The aim of this course is to turn innovative, creative, and inquisitive FinTech students into entrepreneurs through multi-disciplinary, and project-based learning. The course covers topics in disruptive innovation and business models, human centered and design-driven innovation, business plan formulation, start-up pitch, how technology spur entrepreneurship, fundraising, growth, acquisition and IPO, making critical decisions during the journey, in order to equip participants to become entrepreneurs in the FinTech world. Course participants are expected to:1. Learn the basic framework of Opportunity Identification, Venture Design, Resources Mobilization and Execution in Entrepreneurship 2. Acquire refined communication, organizational, and leadership skills for entrepreneurs3. Conduct case-study research on how FinTech entrepreneurship plays an important role in the development of the high-tech industry4. Learn the basic knowledge on IP (patents, copyright, trademarks)5. Take part in a class group project to prepare a business plan and present the research finding on FinTech entrepreneurship
outcome: By the end of this course, student will be able to 1. Have a basic grasp of an Entrepreneurship framework ; 2. Have a good understanding of how FinTech industries are being created, managed, and operated; 3. Have the ability to develop innovative ideas from their inception to potential ventures; 4. Present to financial and technology domain experts in the industry and communicate effectively in pitching for investment from venture capitalists.
syllabus: Week 1: What is entrepreneurship? title: Data Analytics for Financial Technology
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology;Exclusion: CSCI5150
description: The aim of this course is to equip students with essential data analytics techniques for problems in financial technology. Topics covered by this course include linear and general regression, classification techniques such as logistic regression and discriminant analysis, decision trees, support vector machines, principal component analysis, clustering methods, time series models, resampling methods and deep learning models. Various applications in asset management, risk management, asset pricing and financial prediction will be used to illustrate the methods throughout this course. Students also learn how to implement these methods in the popular data analytics software R to analyze financial data.
outcome: By the end of this course, student will be able to 1. understand various data-driven problems in financial technology; 2. understand essential data analytics techniques, including linear and nonlinear regression, classification techniques such as logistic regression, discriminant analysis, decision trees, support vector machines, principal component analysis, clustering methods, time series models, resampling methods and deep learning models, and apply them to solve problems in financial technology; 3. implement all the techniques mentioned in the above point using R to analyze financial data.
syllabus: Week 1: Introduction to data-driven problems in financial technology and review of probability Week 2: Linear regression: least squares, maximum likelihood estimation, analysis of variance, applications in exploring relationship among some financial variables Week 3: Linear regression: trouble-shooting techniques, model selection criteria, applications in estimating factor-based asset price models Week 4: Lasso regression and its applications in factor selection for financial problems, nonlinear regression with applications in yield curve construction Week 5: Classification techniques: logistic regression, discriminant analysis, applications in credit risk analysis Week 6: Decision trees: classification trees, regression trees, random forests, applications in credit risk analysis and financial time series forecasting Week 7: Support vector machines: classifiers, applications in credit risk analysis and financial time series forecasting Week 8: Principal component analysis with applications in the analysis of yield curve changes, clustering methods (K-means and hierarchical clustering) with applications in stock clustering analysis Week 9: Time series models: ARIMA models and its applications in modelling and forecasting financial time series Week 10: Time series models: GARCH models and its applications in modelling and forecasting financial time series Week 11: Resampling methods: bootstrap, applications in estimation of risk measures Week 12: Deep learning: commonly used neural network structures, applications in default prediction and price prediction
required_readings: Course notes will be provided by the instructor.
recommended_readings: 1. G. James, D. Witten, T. Hastie and R. Tibshirani, An Introduction to Statistical Learning with Applications in R, Springer, 2017. 2. D. Ruppert, D S. Matteson, Statistics and Data Analysis for Financial Engineering, Second Edition, Springer, 2015.

title: Intelligent Automation - Robotic Process Automation (RPA) & Artificial Intelligence (AI)
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
description: Intelligent Automation (IA) is software-based automation which executes business processes on behalf of knowledge workers with minimal human intervention. IA combines methods and various technologies, in particular, robotic process automation (RPA) and artificial intelligence. As the core and foundational technology of intelligent automation (IA), robotic process automation (RPA) has been described as a first step on the stairway of intelligent automation towards building digital workers. The aim of this course is to provide learners comprehensive coverage of intelligent automation – including RPA development skills and AI fundamentals– in the context of financial services. This course will build the capabilities of students to an advanced level and will enable participants to actively engage in the full lifecycle of “bot” development from assessment of automation opportunities through the building/deployment of functional automations. The course also introduces students to the latest industry developments in low-code artificial intelligence providing students with less technical backgrounds an opportunity to learn the skills to automate business processes without a need of a computer science background.Course participants are expected to:1. Gain a clear understanding of the intelligent automation (RPA + AI) industry and benefits and understand the limits and constraints of process automation.2. Learn about the role of business analysis in the context of process automation implementation including: (a) how to conduct an automation opportunity assessment; (b) how to map the requirements and deliverables of a process automation project; (c) best practices during the Process Deep Dive stage including ways of compiling comprehensive process-related documentation; (d) testing strategies for an process automation solution; (e) how to conduct trainings and create a User Manual during Go-Live preparations; and (f) how to manage changes throughout the entire process automation development process. 3. Understand the delivery methodology of process automation project/program management including: (a) steps of a process automation implementation, (b) choosing processes suitable for automation, (c) driving/managing process automation projects, and (d) raising intelligent automation awareness throughout an organization.4. Obtain a solid grasp of the technical skills required to create software robots. 5. Be able to build and deploy software robots to automate a variety of manual tasks/process encountered in financial operations.
outcome: By the end of this course, student will:1. Have a comprehensive understanding of intelligent automation [robotic process automation (RPA) + artificial intelligence (AI)) within the context of financial service operations;2. Understand the role of business analysis in intelligent automation implementation;3. Be knowledgeable of and able to execute a delivery methodology for intelligent automation project/program management;4. Possess the technical skills pre-required to create software robots;5. Be capable to build and deploy software robots that can automate a variety of manual tasks/process encountered in financial operations.6. Have created a portfolio of fintech related “bots” that can be showcased to a potential employer.

title: Computational Finance
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology; Not for students who have taken CMSC5718 or SEEM5820
description: This course will introduce pricing models and algorithms in managing the risks and making decisions regarding the trading and analysis of financial assets. Main areas that will be covered include, but not limited to: (i) Models for asset allocation; (ii) Derivative models and products; (iii) Practical applications of financial modelling. Assignments will be set up to help students develop an intuitive understanding of how these models can be implemented.
outcome: After completing this course, students are expected to:1.    understand the relationship between risks and returns, their measurements and relevance in portfolio management;2.    have a basic understanding of modern portfolio theory and some of its extensions;3.    be able to apply optimization techniques to asset allocation strategies;4.    have a basic understanding of pricing and trading strategies related to financial derivatives;5.    be able to apply standard computational techniques in the valuation of vanilla and exotic derivative products.
syllabus: This course introduces some basic concepts in computational finance and their application in real markets. Topics include modern portfolio theory, asset allocation models, utility functions, evaluation of portfolio performance, stochastic models for derivative pricing and trading.  Throughout the course, examples from Asian markets will be used in illustrating the concepts.Week 01:     Introduction; Modern Portfolio Theory (part I)Week 02:     Modern Portfolio Theory (part II)Week 03:     Equilibrium in Capital Markets: CAPM and APTWeek 04:     Practical models in asset allocation: Black-Litterman and Risk ParityWeek 05:     Derivative market and instrumentsWeek 06:     Basic stochastic models and Monte Carlo simulationsWeek 07:     Derivative product analysis (part I)Week 08:     Derivative product analysis (part II)Week 09:     Practical models in asset allocation: Indexing techniques and ESG investingWeek 10:     Portfolio evaluation and risk measuresWeek 11:     Option volatility and hedgingWeek 12:     Quantitative trading strategies involving derivativesWeek 13:     Examination
required_readings: Course notes will be provided by the instructor.
recommended_readings: •    Elton, Edwin, Martin Gruber, Stephen Brown, William Goetzmann. Modern Portfolio Theory and Investment Analysis.  9th edition.  Wiley, 2017.•    Hull, John C.  Options, Futures, and Other Derivatives.  11th edition.  Pearson, 2021.•    Luenberger, David G.  Investment Science.  2nd edition.  Oxford University Press, 2013.•    Sinclair, Euan.  Volatility Trading.  2nd edition.  Wiley, 2013.

title: Wealth Management Business and Fintech
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
description: This course aims to provide students with a practical and management level understanding of how technology is and could be used and applied to the management, growth and development of wealth management business in Hong Kong / Mainland as well as Asia and other parts of the world. Key topics to be discussed include the regulatory framework for wealth management industry, a review of the relationship between macro-economic cycle and wealth management product development and product shelf management strategies, roles and responsibilities of the various players within the wealth management industry value chain to fulfill various stages of individual customers’ financial needs, wealth management business proposition including sales and marketing strategies, and the technology and operational infrastructure required to support and to enhance the business process and to deliver exceptional customer experience.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to explain the key technology  components, enablers and success factors for managing a wealth management business through the market life cycles, and for those students who are interested in developing further academic study and research, or in preparing them to take up senior leadership roles within their company or in the wealth management industry.
syllabus: Week 1   - Wealth management business, industry value chain  and technology overviewWeek 2 / 3 - Discovery of personal financial needs and factors affecting customer behaviour in macroeconomics cycle, designing product development & management process, and current and potential future use of technology in these areasWeek 4 / 5  - Delivery of Excellent Multi-Channel Marketinging, Sales & Services Customer Experience and the role of technologyWeek 6 - Group Project on Applied Technology in Wealth Management Business presentationWeek 7 - Developing the technology solution for implementation of Regulatory, Legal & Compliance FrameworkWeek 8 - Volatility, Financial Crisis & Contingency PlanningWeek 9 - Final Exam
required_readings: Course notes will be provided by the instructor.

title: Green FinTech
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
description: This course focuses on the intersection of green finance and financial technology, equipping students with the knowledge and skills to drive innovation in the green fintech space. It covers a range of topics, from renewable energy finance to sustainable infrastructure, carbon markets, and ESG data management, all within the context of fintech-enabled solutions.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to explain the key technology components, enablers and success factors for a green fintech business, and for those students who are interested in developing further academic study and research, or in preparing them to take up fintech job roles.
syllabus: 1. Introduction to Green Fintech   - Overview of the intersection of green finance and financial technology   - Sustainability challenges and the role of fintech in enabling green finance   - Emerging trends and innovations in the green fintech landscape2. Sustainable Finance Fundamentals   - Environmental, social, and governance (ESG) criteria and their integration in investment decisions   - Sustainable investment strategies and their application in fintech solutions   - Measuring and reporting on sustainability performance using digital tools3. Green Fintech for Renewable Energy   - Financing models for renewable energy projects using digital platforms   - Blockchain-based solutions for renewable energy trading and peer-to-peer transactions   - AI-powered predictive analytics for optimizing renewable energy investments4. Green Fintech for Sustainable Infrastructure   - Fintech-enabled financing for green buildings, transportation, and water/waste management   - Integrating IoT and sensor data to monitor and improve infrastructure sustainability   - Crowd-funding and peer-to-peer lending for sustainable infrastructure projects5. title: Decentralized Finance
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
description: This course provides a foundational introduction to Decentralized Finance (DeFi) with an aim to bridge decentralized/ distributed computing and finance. Students will learn about decentralized systems, distributed consensus, blockchains, smart contracts, and the contrast between DeFi and traditional finance. The course starts with a brief review of the notion of money, conventional banking and payment systems. It then proceeds to cover different DeFi assets including cryptocurrencies, tokens and stablecoins. Various DeFi infrastructure technologies such as Decentralized Exchanges (DEX), Automated Market Maker (AMM) protocols, Decentralized Lending/ Borrowing protocols, and Oracles are also discussed. The course concludes with decentralized governance, DeFi risk management and best practices for DeFi security. By exploring the intricacies of DeFi ecosystems, students will gain a better understanding of the opportunities, challenges, and systemic risks associated with this emerging field.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:1. Understand the operating principles and concepts underlying various DeFi services.2. Explain how cryptocurrencies, tokens, and smart contracts can be used to implement different financial services.3. Evaluate various DeFi services by analyzing their strengths, limitations, potential applications and risks.4. Assess the potential impact of different DeFi services on the financial industry and the society.

title: Topics in International Fintech
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
description: Hong Kong is “Asia’s world city” and an international financial center as well as an emerging innovation hub. Accordingly, it is important for Hong Kong’s fintech students to develop a much broader understanding of the international fintech ecosystems. This course aims to expand students’ knowledge of the fintech landscapes beyond the borders of mainland China and Hong Kong SAR perspectives. The course learning material will help students to appreciate the unique and significant difference of the Hong Kong fintech ecosystems from other international jurisdictions. Students are introduced to the latest international fintech trends and are provided with an overview of the respective ecosystems* of:(1) Africa (Sub-Saharan Africa)(2) Middle East & North Africa(3) Asia (South Asia)(4) East Asia & Pacific(5) Europe and Central Asia(6) Latin America & the Caribbean (7) North America*geographic ecosystems for the course are organized according to the World Bank analytical grouping scheme of seven (7) regions (https://datatopics.worldbank.org/sdgatlas/archive/2017/the-world-by-region.html)The course addresses the concept of techno-business ecosystems via a comprehensive framework including: people/firms, markets, policy/regulation, culture, finance, and infrastructure support.This course will also include a variety of C-suite level and international guest speakers to supplement lecture course material. Topics will be updated year to year.

title: Agentic AI for Business and FinTech
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
description: Traditional AI models can respond to prompts or execute predefined tasks impressively. Agentic AI goes beyond traditional AI by incorporating a "chaining" capability: it can take a “sequence” of actions in response to a single request, breaking down complex tasks into smaller, manageable steps or coordinating among multiple agents to achieve a common goal. Agentic AI systems have a high degree of autonomy and can act with minimal human supervision. Agentic AI could revolutionize business and financial technologies of the future. This course introduces the students to the fundamentals of agentic systems, covering reinforcement learning agents, language model agents, and multi-agent systems. We will cover applications of agentic systems in various aspects of business and fintech, including cryptocurrency/blockchain, financial analysis, portfolio management, customer service, human resources, business planning, and operations.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students are expected to be able to1.    Describe the fundamental technical mechanism underlying reinforcement learning, language models, and agentic systems;2.    Analyze real business and fintech problems and conceptualize feasible agentic systems to address them;3.    Prototype minimal viable agentic systems to address the problems;4.    Evaluate, benchmark, and compare different agentic architectures across multiple metrics and choose the most appropriate agentic system;5.    Deploy the agentic systems successfully under resource constraints.
syllabus: Week 1: Introduction to agentic systems, Revision on machine learning concepts and deep neural networksWeek 2: Reinforcement learning agents (theory)Week 3: Reinforcement learning agent (applications in market simulation, etc.)Week 4: Fundamentals of language models (transformer, tokenization, prompts)Week 5: Language model agent capabilities (memory, reasoning)Week 6: Language model agent capabilities (tool use, planning)Week 7: Language model agents (applications in fintechWeek 8: Multi-agent systems (theory)Week 9: Multi-agent systems (applications in portfolio management and business operations)Week 10: Midterm exam (90 minutes)Week 11: Benchmarking and performance evaluationWeek 12: Safety, alignment, and mechanistic interpretabilityWeek 13: Project presentation
required_readings: There are no required readings. The lecture notes and slides will be self-contained.
recommended_readings: 1.    What Are AI Agents? by Benjamin Labaschin, O'Reilly Media.2.    Reinforcement Learning: An Introduction by Richard S. Sutton and Andrew G. Barto, MIT Press.3.    Build a Large Language Model (From Scratch) by Sebastian Raschka, O’Reilly Media.

title: Financial Technology Entrepreneurship Field Trip
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology; or For students in PgD Financial Technology
description: The course is designed to provide students with knowledge and experiences of entrepreneurship in real-life environment. Students will participate in a week-long field-trip (e.g. in Silicon Valley, Crypto Valley or Singapore, etc.), to visit organisations on various FinTech domains for a close-up on the operation. Course learning activities include lectures/ seminars at universities/ companies, discussions with management of start-up companies, and site visits to enterprises, etc. Through these activities, students will be able to learn practical operational knowledge and experience from FinTech entrepreneurs in close distance.Student should take part in a class group project, to present the research findings on FinTech entrepreneurship and the learning outcomes of the field trip

Learn from the entrepreneurs on how to pursue opportunities and leverage resources within the ecosystem3. Understand the regulatory framework of the city/region

title: AI Applications in FinTech
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology or PgD Financial Technology;Good knowledge in linear algebra, probability, and calculus and familiarity with programming languages C or Python. Some acquaintance on using MATLAB and R is advantageous
description: Characteristics of financial data, patterns, and models, time-series representation and prediction. Limitations of classical system identification for prediction problems. Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) in AI: Recurrent and feedforward neural networks and their learning architectures: matrix computations and fast neural learning hardware realization. Reinforcement learning and dynamic programming. Integration of statistical techniques and neural learning, for applications in financial prediction, investment strategies and planning. Simulation of generative AI for potential applications and their evaluations. Exploring robo-advisors using generative AI with large language model (LLM) for enhancing wealth creation and investment outcomes.
outcome: 1.    Understanding financial time series modeling and basic statistical knowledge for analysis, and estimation2.    Learning basic MATLAB/PYTHON/R programming skill for linear model estimation and identification3.    Understanding artificial neural network and learning schemes, including recurrent and feed-forward architectures, reinforcement learning and dynamic programming4.    Learning MATLAB/PYTHON/R programming skill for neural networks construction and their simulation5.    Understanding the current development of efficient hardware platforms for supporting large scale neural computation6.    Simulations of generative AI for financial prediction, investment strategies and planning7.    Exploring robo-advisors using generative AI with large language models (LLMs) for enhancing wealth creation and investment outcomes.

title: Financial Technology Project I
requirements: For students in MSc Financial Technology
description: The courses, Financial Technology Project I & II, involve a significant research and/or development project under the supervision of an academic staff in any area of financial technology. Unless otherwise approved by the Professor-in-Charge, the project should involve an industrial partner with a co-supervisor from the industry. At the end of the course, the student must give a presentation to the academic and industry supervisors, and submit a report detailing the findings and deliverables. The student’s grade will be determined by the presentation and the report.Unless otherwise approved by the Programme Director, the credits for Financial Technology Project I are recognized if and only if the student takes also Financial Technology Project II in a subsequent semester.If a student has prior industrial background and has already secured a project topic with an industrial practitioner and the agreement of an academic staff, Financial Technology Project I can be taken in the first semester of studies. Otherwise, the two project courses can be taken in any consecutive semesters, including the summer term.Students are encouraged to find industrial projects by themselves and talk to various academic staffs for project ideas before enrolling in the courses.
outcome: At the end of the course of studies, a student should be able to 1. Analyze and solve a significant and practical problem in financial technology; 2. Understand and carry out basic project management; 3. Give a fluent technical presentation; and  4. Write a report detailing the findings and deliverables of the project.
